description: From Middle English vavasour, from Old French vavasour, from Medieval Latin vavassor, perhaps from vassus vassōrum (“vassal of vassals”).

entries.meaning: (historical) a subvassal; someone holding their lands from a vassal of the crown rather than from the crown directly
examples: “Fiddler’s Green is missing? That is passing strange, Lucien. He is, after all, vavasour of his own dominion. And always so… reliable.”
